nodes.content:
Stage IB (peripheral T2a, N0)
Stage I (central T1abc–T2a, N0)
Stage II (T1abc–T2ab, N1; T2b, N0)
Stage IIB (T3, N0)f
Stage IIIA (T3, N1)f

Pretreatment Evaluation
• Molecular testing for EGFR, ALK; PD-L1 testing
• Evaluate for perioperative therapyq
• PFTs (if not previously done)
• Bronchoscopy
• Pathologic mediastinal lymph node evaluationh
• FDG-PET/CT scank (if not previously done)
• Brain MRI with contrastr (stage II, IIIA) (stage IB [optional])
Medically inoperable, high surgical risk as determined by thoracic surgeon,m and those who decline surgery after thoracic surgical consultation
Surgical exploration and resectionm + mediastinal lymph node dissection or systematic lymph node sampling after preoperative systemic therapy, if plannedp
Consider adjuvant chemotherapyn for high-risk stage II (especially T2b–3)

tree_references.description: Next step for surgical cases: Findings at Surgery
Next step for medically inoperable N1 cases
Next step for Stage IIIA/IIIB (N2 or N3)
Next step for Stage IIIB/IIIC (N2 or N3)
Principles of Surgical Therapy (referenced in footnote m)
Principles of Radiation Therapy (referenced in footnote n)
Perioperative Systemic Therapy (referenced in footnote q)

footnotes.label: f
footnotes.content: T3, N0 related to size or satellite nodules.

footnotes.label: g
footnotes.content: Testing is not listed in order of priority and is dependent on clinical circumstances, institutional processes, and judicious use of resources.

footnotes.label: h
footnotes.content: Methods for evaluation include mediastinoscopy, mediastinotomy, EBUS, EUS, and CT-guided biopsy. An EBUS-TBNA negative for malignancy in a clinically (FDG-PET/CT and/or CT) positive mediastinum should undergo subsequent mediastinoscopy prior to surgical resection.

footnotes.label: k
footnotes.content: FDG-PET/CT performed skull base to mid-thigh. Positive FDG-PET/CT scan findings for distant disease need pathologic or other radiologic confirmation. If FDG-PET/CT scan is positive in the mediastinum, lymph node status needs pathologic confirmation.

footnotes.label: p
footnotes.content: Prior to treatment, multidisciplinary evaluation that includes treating physicians and specialists in obtaining tissue diagnosis (thoracic surgery, interventional pulmonology, and interventional radiology) is required to determine the safest and most efficient approach for biopsy, or to provide consensus that a biopsy is too risky or difficult, that a clinical diagnosis of lung cancer is appropriate, and that treatment is warranted.

footnotes.label: r
footnotes.content: If MRI is not possible, CT of head with contrast.

image_title: CLINICAL ASSESSMENT - PRETREATMENT EVALUATION - INITIAL TREATMENT
